p: The renin–angiotensin–aldosterone system (RAAS) inhibitors, ACEi and ARB, confer potent dual effects, not only as cardiovascular protective therapies but also as anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory agents [ 119]. ACE2, the enzyme that converts angiotensin (Ang) I to Ang II, is expressed near the surface of human epithelial cells throughout the body, including the lungs [ 120]. ACE2 receptors are the human cell entry points for SARS-CoV-2 [ 120]. It was shown with SAR-CoV-1 that binding to ACE2 led to its downregulation and increased Ang II [ 120]. There is a theoretical risk that ACEIs and ARBs can increase SARS-CoV-2 attachment by upregulating ACE2 [ 121], although this was not substantiated by any human data and is an urgent research priority.
